Natural Philosophy
5. Natural Philosophy

Coming to natural philosophy, Gregory of Rimini’s conception of
the continuum has been the object of several studies (i.e., Maier 1949,
172–173, 176–177; Cross 1998; Sylla 2005,
260–268). According to Gregory, following Adam Wodeham, the
continuum is not composed of point-like entities, but parts of the
continuum are themselves magnitudes (Cross 1998, 96). Gregory also
claims, this time against Wodeham, that the division of the continuum
can actually be completed, so that it is composed of an actual
infinity of potential extended parts (Cross 1998, 97–98). It is
understood that each of these parts itself includes an infinity of
parts (Cross 1998, 102). That said, a problem is to see how exactly
the division of the continuum can be completed if any part of the
continuum must be said to contain an infinity of parts. It has been
argued that it is in connection with this issue that several scholars
(following Maier 1949, 172–173) read Gregory as holding that
there are infinitesimal parts in the continuum (Cross 1998,
103–104). Yet, in fact, the process is completed, not because
one reaches something that cannot be divided, but because every part
has been actually set apart from the others, including the ones it
contains (Cross 1998, 103). It is in connection with its conception of
a continuum composed of an actual infinity of parts, each themselves
composed of an actual infinity of parts, that Gregory explains how an
infinite can be greater than another by including it (Cross 1998,
105–106; Thakkar 2009, 631–632), thus answering
Bradwardine’s objection on infinite parts and wholes (Thakkar
2009, 628–629).

Gregory’s views on minima naturalia also attracted
attention. Although Gregory acknowledges that there is a minimal
extensive quantity some subject needs to have in order to receive a
given form (Sylla 2011, 403), he rejects the idea that forms of a
given species would have intensive minima, relying on ideas developed
by Richard Kilvington (Knuuttila 1971, 313; Loewe 2014, 320–323).

In general, Gregory’s answer to the problem of the intension and
remission of forms (i.e. how to account for increases or decreases of
a given quality) had a life of its own, since it circulated as a
separate treatise, the Tractatus de intensione et remissione
formarum corporalium (Loewe 2014, 274). Gregory argued that when
intension occurs, a form of the same species is added to the subject,
so that this new form and the preceding form now constitute a total
form that has per se unity (Loewe 2014, 286, 316).
